awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: P2C2: Water Isotopes in Peat Mosses as Proxies for Understanding Climate and Atmospheric Circulation Changes in Southern Patagonia
awd_abstract_narration:
This award to Lehigh and Brown Universities will develop and test a powerful technique to reconstruct atmospheric circulation patterns and moisture trajectories using two water isotopes from peat mosses. The research will generate important climate records that will potentially transform our understanding of climate dynamics of the last 1000 years in the relatively understudied southern hemisphere. This approach is also applicable over longer time scales in this geographic regions, as well as other places Sphagnum moss can be found.  The new climate records from under-studied southern Patagonia will provide a benchmark data set with which to evaluate the climate models that are used for projecting future climate change. The project will train graduate and undergraduate students at both institutions in the application of a state-of-art technology in innovative interdisciplinary research. 

This award will use isotope records to document and understand climate and atmospheric circulation changes in the last millennium using a novel dual water isotope approach and systematic modern calibration from single species peat mosses (Sphagnum) as preserved in peat bogs in southernmost Patagonia (southern South America). The investigators will carry out calibration sampling and analysis to span large latitude and precipitation gradients in southern Patagonia. The isotope records will be derived from the existing peat cores at Lehigh University. In addition to using oxygen and hydrogen isotope time series from cellulose and lipids for ?conventional? paleoclimate interpretations, the team will explore the use of derived deuterium excess (delta-excess) as a tracer for moisture source region conditions and moisture trajectories. This innovative use of dual (O and D) isotopes would provide powerful information regarding past atmospheric circulation and mechanisms of observed climate changes.

por.por_cntn:
A key component of the less appreciated Southern Hemisphere (SH) climate system is the mighty Southern Hemisphere Westerly Winds (SHWW). In recent decades, the SHWW is becoming stronger and shifting poleward due to ozone depletion and global warming. This change has caused re-distribution of atmospheric heat (temperature) and moisture (precipitation) in mid- and high-latitude regions of the SH. In addition, the SHWW regulate Southern Ocean (SO) upwelling system and could impact global ocean circulation and ocean-atmosphere CO2 flux. However, the behaviors and dynamics of SHWW and particularly its interactions with tropical climate system are not fully understood. This knowledge gap has hindered a robust projection of future SHWW-SO coupled system, which however has the potential to impact the global carbon cycle and climate.

In this project, the team of researchers from Lehigh University and Brown University provide new perspectives on SH climate dynamics by studying the isotope ratio information in precipitation, living moss plants, and subfossil peat mosses in southern Patagonia. First, we used atmospheric reanalysis and modeling along with weather station data to show the importance of "unconventional" easterly winds on southern Patagonian precipitation. Although the prevailing SHWW has long been believed to be the moisture conveyor for eastern side of southern Patagonia, our analysis indicates that the occasional easterly incursions, especially when the SHWW is weak or blocked, contribute to many extreme precipitation events in this "Andean rain shadow" region. Second, we showed that the "signal" of westerly and easterly winds could be disentangled by their isotopic ratios in precipitation. Linking isotopic ratios in precipitation and wind direction made it possible for using peat archive to reconstruct the long-term shifts in precipitation source and thus the SHWW strength in the past millennia. Third, we further improve our understanding on how isotope signals in living peat mosses are shaped by plant physiology and peatland hydromorphology. Fourth, with new knowledge learned from modern peat mosses, we used peat-core analysis to document the long-term SHWW variability, with both centennial-scale intensifications and reductions in SHWW strength prevailing over the last two thousand years. In particular, we found that the current mighty SHWW likely is a recent phenomenon, while early 20th century was characterized by much weaker SHWW. Fifth, we found evidence for ENSO-SHWW teleconnection over southern Patagonia on centennial timscale. This finding reinforces the role of tropical generation of Rossby wave chain on influencing SH climate. Sixth, our Patagonia case study has broad implications for the SHWW dynamics, and we provided evidence that synoptic-scale condition is more fundamental than previously thought in regulating the SHWW. We demonstrated that the SHWW "zonal flow' has the "zonal asymmetry" nature. This should be considered in future studies on both SHWW and SO ocean-atmosphere carbon cycle.

The project so far has resulted in three manuscripts, including one already published and two more manuscripts under review; one doctoral dissertation (in progress); and four conference presentations. The grant has supported the training and professional development of two PhD students and two undergraduate students. Also, the project research team were involved in organizing SHWW sessions at VIII Southern Connection Congress in 2016 and AGU Fall Meeting in 2017.
